details.title: On the Lifetime Distribution of Consecutive <formula formulatype="inline"><tex>$k{\hbox{-}}{\hbox{out}}{\hbox{-}}{\hbox{of}}{\hbox{-}}n:{\rm F}$</tex></formula> System

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Math., Izmir Univ. of Econ.

p: Serkan Eryilmaz received a B.S. degree in 1999, a M.S. degree in 2000, and a Ph.D. in 2002 in Statistics from Ankara University, Turkey. He is currently working as an associate professor at the Department of Mathematics, Izmir University of Economics, Turkey. His research interests include applied probability, and statistical distribution theory.

authors.name: Serkan Eryilmaz

details.abstract: A consecutive k-out-of-n:F system is a system of n components which fails iff k consecutive components fail. In this paper, we consider the lifetime of consecutive k-out-of-n:F systems and provide some stochastic ordering results. It is shown that the usual stochastic ordering is preserved under the formation of consecutive k-out-of-n:F systems of s-independent, nonidentical, and exchangeable components. A counter example is also given to show that the mean residual life ordering is not, in general, preserved by a consecutive k-out-of-n:F system

references.title:
Lifetime distributions of consecutive <ref_formula><tex>$k\hbox{-out-of-}n:{\rm
F}$</tex></ref_formula> systems

context.text: Aki & Hirano [1] investigated the lifetime distributions of consecutive \$k{\hbox{-}}{\hbox{out}}{\hbox{-}}{\hbox{of}}{\hbox{-}}n:{\rm F}\$ systems.

references.text: S. Aki, K. Hirano, "Lifetime distributions of consecutive \$khbox{-out-of-}n:{rm F}\$ systems", Nonlinear Anal.-Theor., vol. 30, no. 1, pp. 555-562, 1997.

references.title:
Circular sequential <ref_formula><tex>$k\hbox{-out-of-}n$</tex>
</ref_formula> congestion system

context.text: The papers [2], [10], [13], [14], [19], [20] contribute to the state of the art in consecutive \$k{\hbox{-}}{\hbox{out}}{\hbox{-}}{\hbox{of}}{\hbox{-}}n:{\rm F}\$ systems developments.

links.abstract: A circular sequential k-out-of-n congestion (CSknC) model is presented. This model finds use in reliable systems to prevent single-point failure, such as (k,n) secret key sharing systems. The model assumes that each of the n servers has a known congestion probability. These n servers are arranged in a circle, and are connected sequentially. A server is connected successfully if it is not congested. Previously connected servers are blocked from reconnecting. Congested servers have to be reconnect...

references.text: L. Bai, "Circular sequential \$khbox{-out-of-}n\$ congestion system", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 54, no. 3, pp. 412-420, 2005.

references.title: Runs and Scans With Applications

context.text: We refer to Balakrishnan & Koutras [3], as well as Fu & Lou [9].
It is known that (see, Balakrishnan & Koutras [3]) this conditional distribution \$P\{L_{n}(t)<k\vert S_{n}(t)=m\}\$ is independent of \$F\$.

references.text: N. Balakrishnan, M. Koutras, Runs and Scans With Applications, 2002, Wiley.

references.title:
Stochastic ordering results for consecutive <ref_formula>
<tex>$k\hbox{-out-of-}n:{\rm F}$</tex></ref_formula> systems

context.text: Recently, Boland & Samaniego [4] provided some stochastic ordering results for such a system consisting of \$s\$-independent components.
We extend some of the results of Boland & Samaniego [4] to the system consisting of \$s\$-dependent components.
See, for example, the recent studies of Boland & Samaniego [4], Hu et al. [11], and Korwar [12].

Boland & Samaniego [4] provided stochastic ordering results for consecutive \$k{\hbox{-}}{\hbox{out}}{\hbox{-}}{\hbox{of}}{\hbox{-}}n:{\rm F}\$ systems using the recursive relationships on the reliability of such systems with \$s\$-independent components.

links.abstract: A linear (circular) consecutive k-out-of-n:F system is a system of n linearly (circularly) ordered components which fails if and only if at least k consecutive components fail. We use recursive relationships on the reliability of such systems with independent identically distributed components to show that for any fixed k, the lifetime of a (linear or circular) consecutive k-out-of-n:F system is stochastically decreasing in n. This result also holds for linear systems when the components are ind...

references.text: P. J. Boland, F. J. Samaniego, "Stochastic ordering results for consecutive \$khbox{-out-of-}n:{rm F}\$ systems", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 53, no. 1, pp. 7-10, 2004.

references.title:
Failure distributions of consecutive <ref_formula>
<tex>$k\hbox{-out-of-}n:{\rm F}$</tex></ref_formula> systems

context.text: The lifetime distribution of consecutive \$k{\hbox{-}}{\hbox{out}}{\hbox{-}}{\hbox{of}}{\hbox{-}}n:{\rm F}\$ systems was considered by some researchers including Chen & Hwang [5], Papastavridis [16], and Shanthikumar [18].

links.abstract: Most literature on consecutive-k-out-of-n:F systems gives recursive equations for computing the system reliability. This paper gives a formula for computing the system reliability directly. Using this formula, the system failure distribution is derived. Upper and lower bounds for the system reliability or the system failure distribution are given. Some numerical examples are included.

references.text: R. W. Chen, F. K. Hwang, "Failure distributions of consecutive \$khbox{-out-of-}n:{rm F}\$ systems", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. R-34, pp. 338-341, 1985.

references.title:
On the distribution and expectation of success
runs in nonhomogeneous Markov dependent trials

context.text: Eryilmaz [6], [7] represented the longest run random variable as the maximum order statistic of a sequence whose members are subject to a Markov chain condition.

references.text: S. Erylmaz, "On the distribution and expectation of success runs in nonhomogeneous Markov dependent trials", Statistical Papers, vol. 46, no. 1, pp. 117-128, 2005.

references.title:
Some results associated with
the longest run statistic in a sequence of Markov dependent trials

context.text: Eryilmaz [6], [7] represented the longest run random variable as the maximum order statistic of a sequence whose members are subject to a Markov chain condition.

references.text: S. Erylmaz, "Some results associated with the longest run statistic in a sequence of Markov dependent trials", Applied Mathematics & Computation, vol. 175, pp. 119-130, 2006.

references.title: Distribution theory of runs: A Markov chain approach

context.text: The Markov chain imbedding (MCI) technique introduced by Fu & Koutras [8] has enabled us to derive the exact distribution of the longest run random variables.

references.text: J. C. Fu, M. Koutras, "Distribution theory of runs: A Markov chain approach", Journal of American Statistical Association, vol. 89, pp. 1050-1058, 1994.

references.title: Distribution Theory of Runs and Patterns and Its Applications

context.text: We refer to Balakrishnan & Koutras [3], as well as Fu & Lou [9].
See Fu & Lou [9] for details about the MCI technique.

references.text: J. C. Fu, W. Y. W. Lou, Distribution Theory of Runs and Patterns and Its Applications, 2003, World Scientific Publishing.

references.title:
Combined <ref_formula><tex>$k\hbox{-out-of-}n:{\rm
G}$</tex></ref_formula>, and consecutive <ref_formula><tex>$k(c)\hbox{-out-of-}n:{\rm
G}$</tex></ref_formula> systems

context.text: The papers [2], [10], [13], [14], [19], [20] contribute to the state of the art in consecutive \$k{\hbox{-}}{\hbox{out}}{\hbox{-}}{\hbox{of}}{\hbox{-}}n:{\rm F}\$ systems developments.

links.abstract: Qualification tests for a system are normally carried out according to either a k-out-of-n:G scheme, or a consecutive k/sub c/-out-of-n:G structure. The reliability of a combination of the two systems is evaluated, showing its benefit over each of the individual structures. As expected, the mean time to failure of the combined system is larger than any of them. Generalizations of the analysis are presented for tests with multi-state results, and for dependent tests. Illustrative numerical result...

references.text: A. E. Gera, "Combined \$khbox{-out-of-}n:{rm G}\$ and consecutive \$k(c)hbox{-out-of-}n:{rm G}\$ systems", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 53, no. 4, pp. 523-531, 2004.

references.title:
Likelihood
ratio and mean residual life orders for order statistics of heterogeneous
random variables

context.text: [11], and Korwar [12].

references.text: T. Hu, Z. Zhu, Y. Wei, "Likelihood ratio and mean residual life orders for order statistics of heterogeneous random variables", Probability in the Engineering and Informational Sciences, vol. 15, pp. 259-272, 2001.

references.title:
On stochastic orders for the lifetime of
a <ref_formula><tex>$k\hbox{-out-of-}n:{\rm F}$</tex></ref_formula> system

context.text: See, for example, the recent studies of Boland & Samaniego [4], Hu et al. [11], and Korwar [12].

references.text: R. Korwar, "On stochastic orders for the lifetime of a \$khbox{-out-of-}n:{rm F}\$ system", Probability in the Engineering and Informational Sciences, vol. 17, pp. 137-142, 2003.

references.title:
Consecutive <ref_formula><tex>$k\hbox{-out-of-}r\hbox{-from-}n$</tex>
</ref_formula> system with multiple failure criteria

context.text: The papers [2], [10], [13], [14], [19], [20] contribute to the state of the art in consecutive \$k{\hbox{-}}{\hbox{out}}{\hbox{-}}{\hbox{of}}{\hbox{-}}n:{\rm F}\$ systems developments.

links.abstract: This paper proposes a new model which generalizes the linear consecutive k-out-of-r-from-n system to the case of multiple failure criteria. In this model, the system consists of n linearly ordered elements, and fails iff in any group of r/sub 1/,...,r/sub H/ consecutive elements less than k/sub 1/,...,k/sub H/ elements respectively are in a working state. An algorithm for system reliability evaluation is suggested which is based on an extended universal moment generating function. Examples of sy...

references.text: G. Levitin, "Consecutive \$khbox{-out-of-}rhbox{-from-}n\$ system with multiple failure criteria", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 53, no. 3, pp. 394-400, 2004.

references.title:
An <ref_formula><tex>$O(k^{2}\log(n))$</tex>
</ref_formula> algorithm for computing the reliability of consecutive <ref_formula>
<tex>$k\hbox{-out-of-}n:{\rm F}$</tex></ref_formula> systems

context.text: The papers [2], [10], [13], [14], [19], [20] contribute to the state of the art in consecutive \$k{\hbox{-}}{\hbox{out}}{\hbox{-}}{\hbox{of}}{\hbox{-}}n:{\rm F}\$ systems developments.

links.abstract: This study presents an O(k/sup 2//spl middot/log(n)) algorithm for computing the reliability of a linear as well as a circular consecutive-k-out-of-n: F system. The proposed algorithm is more efficient and much simpler than the O(k/sup 3//spl middot/log(n/k)) algorithm of Hwang & Wright.

references.text: M. S. Lin, "An \$O(k^{2}log(n))\$ algorithm for computing the reliability of consecutive \$khbox{-out-of-}n:{rm F}\$ systems", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 53, no. 1, pp. 3-6, 2004.

references.title:
Stochastic dominance of random variables implies the dominance
of their order statistics

context.text: It is known that if \$(T_{1}, T_{2},\ldots, T_{n})\mathop{\geq}\limits_{st}(Z_{1},Z_{2},\ldots,Z_{n})\$, then \$T_{1:n}\mathop{\geq}\limits_{st}Z_{1:n}\$ (see, Mi & Shaked [15]).

references.text: J. Mi, M. Shaked, "Stochastic dominance of random variables implies the dominance of their order statistics", J. Indian Statist. Assoc., vol. 40, pp. 161-168.

references.title:
Lifetime distribution of circular consecutive <ref_formula>
<tex>$k\hbox{-out-of-}n:{\rm F}$</tex></ref_formula> systems with exchangeable
lifetimes

context.text: The lifetime distribution of consecutive \$k{\hbox{-}}{\hbox{out}}{\hbox{-}}{\hbox{of}}{\hbox{-}}n:{\rm F}\$ systems was considered by some researchers including Chen & Hwang [5], Papastavridis [16], and Shanthikumar [18].

links.abstract: A recursive algorithm for computing the lifetime distribution of a circular consecutive-k-out-of-n:F system with statistically exchangeable component lifetimes is presented. The result applies to a load-sharing model.

references.text: S. G. Papastavridis, "Lifetime distribution of circular consecutive \$khbox{-out-of-}n:{rm F}\$ systems with exchangeable lifetimes", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 38, no. 4, pp. 460-461, 1989.

references.title: Stochastic Orders and Their Applications

context.text: (Shaked & Shanthikumar [17]) Let \$\{\xi_{i},i\geq1\}\$, and \$\{\varphi_{i},i\geq1\}\$ be two Markov processes.
B.6 of Shaked & Shanthikumar [17] \$(T_{1}, T_{2},\ldots, T_{n})\mathop{\geq}\limits_{st}(Z_{1},Z_{2},\ldots,Z_{n})\$ whenever \$a\leq b\$.

references.text: M. Shaked, J. G. Shanthikumar, Stochastic Orders and Their Applications, 1994, Academic Press.

references.title:
Lifetime distribution of consecutive <ref_formula>
<tex>$k\hbox{-out-of-}n:{\rm F}$</tex></ref_formula> systems with exchangeable
lifetimes

context.text: The lifetime distribution of consecutive \$k{\hbox{-}}{\hbox{out}}{\hbox{-}}{\hbox{of}}{\hbox{-}}n:{\rm F}\$ systems was considered by some researchers including Chen & Hwang [5], Papastavridis [16], and Shanthikumar [18].

links.abstract: Algorithms for computing the lifetime distributions of consecutive-k-out-of-n:F systems with statistically independent, and statistically exchangeable component lifetimes are presented. A load-sharing model for statistically exchangeable component lifetimes and the effects of minimal repair on system lifetime are considered.

references.text: J. G. Shanthikumar, "Lifetime distribution of consecutive \$khbox{-out-of-}n:{rm F}\$ systems with exchangeable lifetimes", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. R-34, no. 5, pp. 480-483, 1985.

references.title:
Repairable consecutive <ref_formula><tex>$k\hbox{-out-of-}n:{\rm
G}$</tex></ref_formula> systems with <ref_formula><tex>$r$</tex></ref_formula> repairmen

context.text: The papers [2], [10], [13], [14], [19], [20] contribute to the state of the art in consecutive \$k{\hbox{-}}{\hbox{out}}{\hbox{-}}{\hbox{of}}{\hbox{-}}n:{\rm F}\$ systems developments.

links.abstract: In this paper, we study repairable consecutive-k-out-of-n: G systems with r repairmen. The systems are either circular or linear. It is assumed that the working time, and the repair time of each component in the system are both exponentially distributed; and every component after repair is 'as good as new'. Each component is classified as either a key component, or an ordinary one according to its priority role to the system's repair. By using the definition of generalized transition probability...

references.text: Y. Q. Wu, J. C. Guan, "Repairable consecutive \$khbox{-out-of-}n:{rm G}\$ systems with \$r\$ repairmen", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 54, no. 2, pp. 328-337, 2005.

references.title:
Recursive formulas for the reliability of multi-state consecutive <ref_formula>
<tex>$k\hbox{-out-of-}n:{\rm G}$</tex></ref_formula> systems

context.text: The papers [2], [10], [13], [14], [19], [20] contribute to the state of the art in consecutive \$k{\hbox{-}}{\hbox{out}}{\hbox{-}}{\hbox{of}}{\hbox{-}}n:{\rm F}\$ systems developments.

links.abstract: In this paper, we provide an algorithm for evaluating the system state distribution for any multi-state consecutive-k-out-of-n:G system including the decreasing multi-state G system, the increasing multi-state G system, and other G systems. We evaluated our proposed algorithms in terms of the orders of computation time, and memory requirement. Furthermore, we conducted a numerical experiment to determine the actual computation time. Our proposed algorithm is more effective for systems with a lar...

references.text: H. Yamamoto, M. J. Zuo, T. Akiba, Z. Tian, "Recursive formulas for the reliability of multi-state consecutive \$khbox{-out-of-}n:{rm G}\$ systems", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 55, no. 1, pp. 98-104, 2006.
